IRS990.MissionDescription: Colby seeks to provide a unique educational experience and a broad acquaintance with human knowledge to enable each student to fulfill his or her own unique potential.
IRS990.Description: Post secondary Education: Instruction of 1,838 undergraduate students in 2009-10. 481 were graduated in the 2009-10 year. This includes expenditures for faculty, dormitories and dining, student and academic support services, campus maintenance services and other related costs.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: The College paid $3,000 in dues to various organizations, some portion of which may be used for lobbying in connection with issues that impact higher education.

OtherAssets.Description: Funds held in trust by others
Investments in land and real estate

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Founded in 1959 and now comprising four wings, more than 6,000 works, and more than 28,000 square feet of exhibition space, the Colby College Museum of Art has built a significant permanent collection that specializes in American and contemporary art. The Museum is part of the Bixler Art and Music Center, a building named in honor of President J. Seelye Bixler (1942-1960) in recognition of his visionary support for the arts at Colby. The Museum serves both as a teaching resource for Colby College and as an active cultural institution for the residents of Maine and visitors to the state.
The College's endowment funds provide income and support for the furtherance of the educational mission of the College.

The College accounts for the effect of any uncertain tax positions based on a "more likely than not" threshold to the recognition of the tax positions being sustained based on the technical merits of the position under scrutiny by the applicable taxing authority. If a tax position or positions are deemed to result in uncertainties of those positions, the unrecognized tax effect is estimated based on a "cumulative probability assessment" that aggregates the estimated tax liability for all uncertain tax positions. The College has identified its tax status as a tax exempt entity as a tax position; however, the College has determined that such tax position does not result in an uncertainty requiring recognition. The College is not currently under examination by any taxing jurisdictions. The College's Federal and state tax returns are generally open for examination for three years following the date filed.
Post retirement benefit cost change ($1,293,000), Accretion of asset retirement obligation $42,000, Change in annuity and life income fund $548,000
Post retirement benefit cost change $1,293,000, Change in Annuity and Life Income Fund ($548,000)

IRS990ScheduleE.PubViaBroadcastMediaExpln: Annual publication of non-discriminatory policy in the region's largest newspaper, the Boston Globe.
IRS990ScheduleE.GovtFinancialAidExplanation: The College receives government grants for financial aid to students, faculty research, support of various innovative academic programs and energy related projects.

GrantsToIndOutsideUS.Region: Russia and the newly independent States

Form990ScheduleFPartIV.Explanation: Grants to students are made in accordance with Federal and Institutional Financial Aid policies. The grant funds are used for academic course work for foreign study-abroad. The Registrar's Office determines that academic standards are met before academic credit is received by the student.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Grants are made and monitored in accordance with Federal and Institutional Financial Aid policies. Amounts are applied to student accounts as credits to the bill at the bursar's office to offset academic charges.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Charter travel- William D. Adams. The College does not provide first class travel. Charter travel is only permitted for William D. Adams in limited circumstances and occurs rarely. Travel for companions- William D. Adams. Travel for companions is solely permitted when the companion's travel is in furtherance of the College's business purposes. Indemnification and gross-up payments- all officers (7). Housing allowance or residence- William D. Adams. Housing allowance provided as a working condition fringe benefit. All benefits were provided in accordance with written College policies. None of the benefits were treated as taxable compensation except for indemnification and gross-up payments, which were considered taxable compensation to all officers (7).
President William D. Adams participates in a deferred compensation arrangement. The amount earned in fiscal year 2010 under the program totaled $25,000.
Bonus amounts reported on Schedule J, Part II, column (B)(ii) are determined by the Board of Trustees.

Base compensation in Schedule J, Part II, column (B)(i) includes employee deferrals to the College's section 403(b) plan in accordance with the 2009 Form 990 instructions. Comparable amounts were reported by the College on the prior Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, column (B)(iii) in accordance with then applicable IRS instructions.

LoanTable.PurposeOfLoan: mortgage on primary residence made in accordance with College mortgage loan program

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: Schedule M, Part I, Line 32b - The College utilizes financial services firms to assist with the sales of publicly traded securities, real estate and other similar non-cash gifts. All transactions are conducted at arms-length and for good and sufficient consideration.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The return is reviewed by an independent accounting firm and the audit subcommittee of the Board of Trustees. The College provides an electronic copy of the full IRS Form 990 via a password protected web-site on which the form may be viewed by all voting members of the Board of Trustees prior to filing.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Conflict of Interest questionnaire is completed annually by all members of the Board of Trustees, all Officers and all Key Employees. The completed questionnaires are reviewed by College management and any potential conflicts are discussed with the Audit Subcommittee of the Board of Trustees. The Audit Subcommittee will enforce compliance with the Conflict of Interest policy. Any individual with a conflict of interest is prohibited from participating in deliberations and decisions involving the transaction.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: For the President's compensation, a comparison to peer institutions is undertaken annually. In addition, each year an independent compensation consultant is engaged to assess the reasonableness of the compensation amount. The President's compensation amount is reviewed and approved annually by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees. For all other Officers and Key Employees, a comparison to peer institutions is undertaken annually. The College President will recommend the annual compensation amounts for all other Officers and Key Employees, which are reviewed and approved annually by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees. Compensation of the President, Officers and Key Employees is set by independent persons and documented contemporaneously.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 17
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The College is not required to file Form 990 in any state.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annual financial statement is available on Colby's public web-site. Other governing documents and the conflict of interest policy are made available to the public upon request.

The amount included on Form 990, Schedule K, Part I, represents the par value of the College's portion of each pooled bond issue. The issue price listed on Form 8038, Part III, Line 21(b), includes proceeds for other institutions in addition to the College as follows: Line A- $60,650,695 (CUSIP #560425MY3), Line B- $50,233,325 (CUSIP #560425VW7), Line C- $14,200,000 (CUSIP #XXX-XX-XXXX), Line D- $97,716,087 (CUSIP #560425L40, Line E- $72,040,461 (CUSIP #560425V72), Line A (2nd page)- $48,451,841 (CUSIP #560525Z78), Line B (2nd page)- $96,755,000 (CUSIP #560427HX7)

The legal Charitable Trusts names, which include donor/contributor names, have been omitted to protect the privacy of the donor/contributor. Such information is immediately available to the IRS upon request.
